message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Optimization-Based Collision Avoidance
Paper Abstract: This article presents a novel method for exactly reformulating nondifferentiable collision avoidance constraints into smooth, differentiable constraints using strong duality of convex optimization. We focus on a controlled object whose goal is to avoid obstacles while moving in an n-dimensional space. The proposed reformulation is exact, does not introduce any approximations, and applies to general obstacles and controlled objects that can be represented as the union of convex sets. We connect our results with the notion of signed distance, which is widely used in traditional trajectory generation algorithms. Our method can be applied to generic navigation and trajectory planning tasks, and the smoothness property allows the use of general-purpose gradient- and Hessian-based optimization algorithms. Finally, in case a collision cannot be avoided, our framework allows us to find "least-intrusive" trajectories, measured in terms of penetration. We demonstrate the efficacy of our framework on an automated parking problem, where our numerical experiments suggest that the proposed method is robust and enables real-time optimization-based trajectory planning in tight environments. Sample code of our example is provided at https://github.com/XiaojingGeorgeZhang/OBCA.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I found comprehensive information on duality in convex optimization. Here are the key concepts:

## Overview

In general, the optimal values of the primal and dual problems need not be equal. Their difference is called the duality gap.

## Strong and Weak Duality

For convex optimization problems, the duality gap is zero under a constraint qualification condition. This fact is called strong duality.(no content)The optimal solution to the dual program is a lower bound for the optimal solution of the original (primal) program; this is the weak duality principle.

## Conditions for Strong Duality

If the primal problem is convex and bounded from below, and there exists a point in which all nonlinear constraints are strictly satisfied (Slater's condition), then the optimal solution to the dual program equals the optimal solution of the primal program; this is the strong duality principle.(no content)Informally, Slater's condition states that the feasible region must have an interior point.

## Practical Applications

Solving the primal and dual programs together is often easier than solving only one of them.(no content)The convex conjugate is widely used for constructing the dual problem in optimization theory, thus generalizing Lagrangian duality.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Solving the primal and dual programs together is often easier than solving only one of them.(no content)The convex conjugate is widely used for constructing the dual problem in optimization theory, thus generalizing Lagrangian duality.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about trajectory planning:

## Overview

Trajectory optimization is the process of designing a trajectory that minimizes (or maximizes) some measure of performance while satisfying a set of constraints.(no content)Generally speaking, trajectory optimization is a technique for computing an open-loop solution to an optimal control problem.

## Applications

There are a wide variety of applications for trajectory optimization, primarily in robotics: industry, manipulation, walking, path-planning, and aerospace. Specific applications include:

- Robotic manipulators with redundancy can optimize trajectories to avoid obstacles in the workspace or minimize torque in the joints.
- Trajectory optimization is often used to compute trajectories for quadrotor helicopters.
- Applications include path planning for autonomous vehicles, aerial robotics with dynamic constraints, robotic arm manipulation, and legged locomotion.

## Key Planning Concepts

In robotics and motion planning, kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

## Planning Methodologies

Popular approaches include extensions of RRT algorithms such as RRT* for kinodynamic systems, and sampling-based methods like Model Predictive Path Integral (MPPI) control.(no content)Recent advances in mixed-integer programming have enabled new deterministic approaches to kinodynamic planning that simultaneously determine the spatial path and control sequence while respecting all kinodynamic constraints.

Web search results for query: "Distance function geometry"

Links: [{"title":"Distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance"},{"title":"Metric space - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metric_space"},{"title":"Euclidean distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_distance"},{"title":"Distance geometry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance_geometry"},{"title":"Signed distance function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signed_distance_function"},{"title":"Weyl distance function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weyl_distance_function"},{"title":"Taxicab geometry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taxicab_geometry"},{"title":"Minkowski distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minkowski_distance"},{"title":"Distance (graph theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eccentricity_(graph_theory)"},{"title":"Distance from a point to a line - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point-line_distance"}]

Here are the results for "Distance function geometry":

## Overview

The distance is measured by a function called a metric or distance function.(no content)Metric spaces are a general setting for studying many of the concepts of mathematical analysis and geometry, with the most familiar example being 3-dimensional Euclidean space with its usual notion of distance.

## Key Types of Distance Functions

**Euclidean Distance**: The Euclidean distance between two points in a Euclidean space is the length of the line segment between them, calculated from the Cartesian coordinates using the Pythagorean theorem.

**Signed Distance Function**: The signed distance function or signed distance field (SDF) is the orthogonal distance of a given point to the boundary of a set in a metric space.(no content)Signed distance functions are applied in real-time rendering and computer vision.

**Taxicab Distance**: Taxicab geometry defines the distance between two points as the sum of the absolute differences of their respective Cartesian coordinates.

**Minkowski Distance**: The Minkowski distance is a metric in a normed vector space which can be considered as a generalization of both the Euclidean distance and the Manhattan distance.

## Specialized Applications

Distance geometry is the branch of mathematics concerned with characterizing and studying sets of points based only on given values of the distances between pairs of points, or more abstractly, the study of semimetric spaces and isometric transformations between them.

I've completed the web search for "Convex optimization". Here's a summary of what I found:

## Key Definition

Convex optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that studies the problem of minimizing convex functions over convex sets (or, equivalently, maximizing concave functions over convex sets).

## Important Properties

Every point that is a local minimum is also a global minimum in convex optimization problems, which is a significant advantage. Many classes of convex optimization problems admit polynomial-time algorithms, making them computationally tractable.

## Solution Methods

Different approaches are used depending on the problem structure:

- The convex programs easiest to solve are the unconstrained problems or those with only equality constraints, which can be eliminated with linear algebra.
- For unconstrained problems with a general convex objective that is twice-differentiable, Newton's method can be used, reducing the problem to a sequence of quadratic problems.
- For problems with inequality constraints, a common approach is to reduce them to unconstrained problems by adding a barrier function to the objective function, using interior point methods.

## Applications

Convex optimization is used in portfolio optimization, variations of statistical regression, model fitting for multiclass classification, and electricity generation optimization.

Links: [{"title":"Gradient descent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_descent"},{"title":"Stochastic gradient descent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent"},{"title":"Newton's method in optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton's_method_in_optimization"},{"title":"Line search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_search"},{"title":"Nelder–Mead method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nelder–Mead_method"},{"title":"Mirror descent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mirror_descent"},{"title":"Gauss–Newton algorithm","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauss–Newton_algorithm"},{"title":"Yurii Nesterov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yurii_Nesterov"},{"title":"Differential evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_evolution"},{"title":"Hill climbing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hill_climbing"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of gradient descent optimization based on the search results:

## What is Gradient Descent?

Gradient descent is a method for unconstrained mathematical optimization and is a first-order iterative algorithm for minimizing a differentiable multivariate function.(no content)The idea is to take repeated steps in the opposite direction of the gradient (or approximate gradient) of the function.

## Key Characteristics

One starts with a guess and moves against the gradient toward the local minimum. The process iterates until convergence is achieved.

## Variants and Improvements

Several variations of gradient descent have been developed to improve performance:

1. **Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD)**: SGD replaces the actual gradient (calculated from the entire data set) by an estimate thereof (calculated from a randomly selected subset of the data).(no content)This reduces computational burden, achieving faster iterations in exchange for a lower convergence rate.

2. **Momentum Methods**: The momentum method uses a momentum term analogous to a heavy ball sliding on the surface of values of the function being minimized, and remembers the solution update at each iteration.

3. **Adaptive Learning Rates**: In the 2010s, adaptive approaches with per-parameter learning rates were introduced with AdaGrad (2011) and RMSprop (2012), followed by Adam in 2014.(no content)As of 2023, approaches to optimization in machine learning are dominated by Adam-derived optimizers.

## Applications

Stochastic gradient descent serves as the most basic algorithm used for training most deep networks today.(no content)When combined with the backpropagation algorithm, it is the de facto standard algorithm for training artificial neural networks.

I've completed a web search for "Collision avoidance." Here's a summary of the results:

## Collision Avoidance Overview

Collision avoidance systems exist across multiple domains:

**Automotive:**
A collision avoidance system (CAS), also known as a pre-crash system, forward collision warning system (FCW), or collision mitigation system, is an advanced driver-assistance system designed to prevent or reduce the severity of a collision.(no content)Once an impending collision is detected, these systems provide a warning to the driver. When the collision becomes imminent, they can take action autonomously without any driver input (by braking or steering or both).

**Aviation:**
A traffic alert and collision avoidance system (TCAS), also known as an Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS), is an aircraft collision avoidance system designed to reduce the incidence of mid-air collision (MAC) between aircraft. It monitors the airspace around an aircraft for other aircraft equipped with a corresponding active transponder, independent of air traffic control, and warns pilots of the presence of other transponder-equipped aircraft which may present a threat of MAC.

**Maritime:**
Maritime Collision Avoidance Systems (MCAS) are integrated technologies used to prevent collisions and groundings at sea by enhancing vessel situational awareness. These systems combine data from multiple onboard sensors such as radar, AIS, GPS, sonar, and compass, with real-time processing algorithms, often employing artificial intelligence, to issue navigational alerts, assess risks, or initiate corrective actions.

**Networking:**
Carrier-sense multiple access with collision avoidance (CSMA/CA) in computer networking, is a link layer multiple access method in which carrier sensing is used. Under CSMA/CA, nodes attempt to avoid collisions by beginning transmission only after the channel is sensed to have no traffic.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Perfect! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Triples Extracted (6 total):**

1. **Collision avoidance system** (task) - proposes
   - The paper proposes a novel method for collision avoidance constraints using optimization techniques.

2. **Convex optimization** (concept) - uses
   - The method leverages strong duality of convex optimization to reformulate collision avoidance constraints.

3. **Duality (optimization)** (concept) - uses
   - Strong duality is used as the theoretical foundation for the exact reformulation of nondifferentiable constraints.

4. **Trajectory optimization** (task) - uses
   - The paper applies the collision avoidance framework to trajectory optimization and planning tasks.

5. **Gradient descent** (method) - uses
   - The smooth reformulation enables the use of gradient-based optimization algorithms for solving trajectory planning problems.

6. **Signed distance function** (concept) - uses
   - The paper connects its reformulation with the notion of signed distance used in traditional trajectory generation algorithms.

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

The triples_output.json file has been successfully populated with all identified technologies and methodologies from the paper, properly categorized with their Wikipedia references and relevance descriptions.
